results.title: Max Stephens talks about frameworks
results.brief_description: Max Stephens addresses a meeting at Horsham in June 1987 to explain the stage of development that the Curriculum frameworks project had then reached. The program outlines the basis and approach to learning emphasised by the Frameworks project and also looks at the implementation of tasks. No other credits available.

results.title: Preparing your child for school. Parts 1 & 2
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, Glenn McIver, Trevor Lunn and Healthsharing Women. Publishing and Production Group
results.brief_description: Part 1. Discussion is centered on helping children handle being separated from their parents, relating to other children and adults, gaining independence and responsibility in new situations and encouraging curiosity and confidence. Part 2. Encompasses a number of practical considerations which parents will find helpful in preparing their child for school, such as clothing, lunches and school bags.

results.title: What we do at kindergarten
results.creator_credit: Dianne Milwright, Donn Clauscen, Pamela Eagles and Myles-Milwright Productions
results.brief_description: Shows daily activities in kindergartens emphasising the extent activities aid the preschool child’s development. Suitable for use with parents of kindergarten age children and for infant primary teachers as a background knowledge of what happens in kindergartens.

results.title: Early Melbourne: from village to town
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, Lily Steiner, Seven Network Limited (Australia) and TV Ed Productions
results.brief_description: Dr Bernard Barrett, State Historian, discusses the early development of Melbourne, covering such topics as the naming of Melbourne, who decided where the streets would be located and what they would be called.

results.title: Stroke - a blow against life
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, Geoff Owen-Taylor and Australian Brain Foundation

results.title: Natural language learning
results.brief_description: A look at the natural language or whole language approach to the learning of language in the early years of school. This approach is based on the assumption that literacy develops naturally through the use of language as a whole, such as learning to read to follow directions, for information, and to find out about the world. This video also deals with assessment and evaluation and is a good memory jogger for teaches and consultants.

results.title: Bush tucker man
results.creator_credit: Vincent Donovan and Australia. Dept. of Defence
results.brief_description: The Australian Army’s botanist, Major Les Hiddins is studying the natural survival resources of the vast wilderness of northern Australia. This study takes into account the native bush foods and medicines that have sustained Aboriginal people and is the first study of its kind since European settlement. It provides valuable information for Australian soldiers should they ever have to survive in such an inhospitable region. Some unique flora is also discovered. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: The Cutting edge: Australia's Operational Deployment Force in action
results.creator_credit: Stafford Garner and Stafford Garner and Associates
results.brief_description: In October 1986, Orange land forces invaded central Queensland to sabotage Australia’s coal export industry. To counter the threat, the Townsville-based Operational Deployment Force (the cutting edge of the Australian Army) was deployed against them. For the first time, the combat capabilities of the Operational Development Force was being tested. “Jordo” (Private Paul Jordan) was part of the Force assigned to defend our local resources. The Army cameras went into battle with “Jordo” and his platoon.
